column1: Charles Goodyear was born at New Haven
column3: in 1801. He was the eldest of the six children of a leading hardware merchant of that place
column4: a man both of piety and of inventive talent. When Charles was a boy
column5: his father began the manufacture of hardware articles
column6: and at the same time carried on a farm. He often required his son's assistance
column7: so that Charles's schooling was limited. He was very fond of books
column10: and instead of playing with his mates
column11: devoted most of his leisure time to reading.It was even while he was a schoolboy that his attention was first turned to the material
column12: the improvement of which for common uses became afterwards his life-work. "He happened to take up a thin scale of India-rubber
column13: says his biographer, peeled from a bottle
column14: and it was suggested to his mind that it would be a very useful fabric if it could be made uniformly so thin
column15: and could be so prepared as to prevent its melting and sticking together in a solid mass." Often afterward he had a vivid presentiment that he was destined by Providence to achieve these results.
